statement.p: Suppose that as dry air rose its temperature dropped in a linear fashion. The temperature was measured at 900 ft MSL as \displaystyle{22}^{\circ} C and at 1900 ft MSL as \displaystyle{24}^{\circ} C.
What is the rate of change of temperature with respect to altitude? Preview Question 1 Part 1 of 2 Â
Your response may be as a fraction such as 2/1000 or decimal such as 0.002
What does this data imply about the temperature at 0 ft MSL?

solution.p: We want the ratio of temperature drop to altitude increase. \displaystyle\frac{{{24}-{22}}}{{{1900}-{900}}}=-{0.002}

Now that we know that ratio we can use a linear model to find the temperature at sea level. Because the temperature increases (we are going down not up) at a rate of -2 per 1000 ft the temperature will be expected to increase \displaystyle{900}{\left(-\frac{{2}}{{1000}}\right)}=-{1.8}. That will result in a temperature of \displaystyle{22}\pm{1.8}={20.2}.
